label = mx.sym.Variable("softmax")
logicr= mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data=fc1, label=label)

@albertyou2 Would your mind explaining a bit what your code doing? Thanks.

```
def NeuralNet1(num_hidden=2400, activation_fun="relu"):
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    fc1  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = data, name='fc1', num_hidden=num_hidden)
    act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, name='relu1', act_type=activation_fun)
    fc2  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act1, name='fc2', num_hidden=12)
    return mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data = fc2, name = 'softmax')

nn1600_relu = mx.model.FeedForward(
    symbol=NeuralNet1(1600, "relu"), 
    num_epoch=1, learning_rate=0.05, wd=0.0001, momentum=0.9)
nn1600_relu.fit(X=itertrain, eval_metric=log_loss, eval_data=itervalid)
```

So what's the meaning of that argument `Map<String, String>`

`Map<String, String>` is the attributes passed to the `Variable`. If you do not need one, pass it as `null`. Scala supports default function argument while Java does not. Maybe we shall also provide Java-friendly apis.

@piiswrong , I tested the code both in cpu and gpu mode and the results are similar(produce different outputs). Thus, at least in the cpu mode, I assume the difference may come from the numeric error you mentioned.
However, the difference is actually not that "slight". It often leads to different prediction results. I am not sure if it can really be called a normal numeric error.
For instance, if I feed a image of duck into these two models, the predicted top 5 classes are just slightly different:

```

rank 2(prob=0.0348): n01855672 goose

cc @jermainewang

good job. I think one main goal is we wan to make sure that the tracer is limited to the enough code, without changing other parts. 
- Is it possible to remove need_tracer args in the executor, so it is all up to the engine
- Put the op name in the last argument of engine and make it optional as const char*, so when it is turned off, there is no overhead except for the names.

@tqchen 

> Put the op name in the last argument of engine and make it optional as const char*, so when it is turned off, there is no overhead except for the names.

Sounds good.

> Is it possible to remove need_tracer args in the executor, so it is all up to the engine

This is a problem Minjie and I have discussed before. There exists a problem if we just depend on a state variable to decide whether to record (as the current implementation of TurnTracerOn/Off). The tracer may only record the end of operation execution because the execution is asynchronous. (Missed Record Start => TurnOnTracer => Record End) or (Record Start => TurnOffTracer => Miss Record End).

But need_tracer can solve this problem, it's a variable to indicate engine whether to record this operation execution. We encourage users to use TurnOnTracer only when they ensure the execution synchronization.

Besides, need_tracer is only used to record symbolic operation (fc, relu, conv... passed by executor), but when you do TurnOnTracer, all operations including NDArray operation will be recorded. This is another difference.

I think we can solve this in a different way. Something like 

```
SetTracerMode(SymbolicOnly)
```

Where these states can be queried by executor. This enables us to not breach the executor interface

You suggestion sounds good, but I have 2 comments about it.
1. Most of questions on stackoverflow are not answered correctly, because there are few people focusing on mxnet. Questions in github issues are the same, though there are much more people than stackoverflow. I think it's better to make mxnet community more active first rather than separating questions.
2. Compared to tensorflow, mxnet is lack of documentation and nice example/tutorial, so many people don't know how to use it.
   If you are an engineer, you may realize how it works by tracing code. But, if you are just a data scientist, you may not comprehend mxnet in detail.

So, we may do following to solve your problem.
- Answer the problem(not issue) as possible.
- Share our experience in problem.
- Suggest people to post question on stackoverflow in the same time.
- Help mxnet fill the documents/tutorials.

@piiswrong 
Cool, Profiler seems a better name indeed.

Uh, I have thought to use env variable to control tracer, but it will raise some problems:
- we usually do some dry run to boot device first, then the real execution round we want to record, as you can see in [test_symbolic.py](https://github.com/ZihengJiang/mxnet/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_tracer_symbolic.py#L103).
- It's ok to record all symbolic operation for the entire script. But if you try to record overall operation including NDArray operation, the trace file will be very large like hundreds of MB.

Out of the reasons above, I think it's perhaps necessary to manually control in the execution code.
@ZihengJiang Can we have two env variable? One for turn on NDArray recording, another for symbolic executor recording.

I guess you have cast the matrix as ints or bools and the FeedForward function casts it back to floats? Perhaps you can just copy 389-455 from [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/model.R) and adjust appropriately?

Dataset Param: Label csv path. If is NULL, all labels will be returned as 0}
```

Since that seems to accept strings?

OK, let's discuss what kind of API do we want.  @tqchen @piiswrong 

**Goal**
1. Choose to record symbolic operations or all operations.
2. Record certain rounds of execution in the middle of running procedure to exclude some deviation like booting device time and avoid large trace file. 

**Why symbolic operation is special from other operation?**
- symbolic operation is those core operations we intend to focus on. Too much operations will make the trace a mess and large trace file.
- symbolic operation can be separated out. it's only passed by graph_executor.
- symbolic operation have the concept of `round` or `iteration` obviously by executor.forward/backward. As for other operations, you don't know which iteration it belong to because of asynchronisation of operation execution.

**API Design**

**Env Variables**

MXNET_PROFILER_SYMBOLIC: profiler will be turned on to record only symbolic operation.
MXNET_PROFILER_ALL: profiler will be turned on to record all operation.

But if we only have these two env variables, we cannot achieve the second goal. So we need to point out which execution round we want to record explicitly.

**Python APIs**

```
turn_tracer_on()/turn_tracer_off()
```

Turn on/off the profiler to record execution during the interval.

```
model.fit(...num_iterations=None,
              begin_tracing_iteration=None,
              end_tracing_iteration=None,...)
```

It indicates profiler to record execution from the begin iteration to the end iteration.

`need_tracer` acts as the same role to tell engine which execution round should be recorded. It can be removed from executor api as Tianqi said.

Beside, maybe you want to specify the output filename as an env variable too, right? like MXNET_PROFILER_FILENAME
yes, I think that's my next step

@tqchen Since I am still confused about this async engine, may I ask you one more question? Like you said before, executor.outputs[0].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy() will force the engine to sync. So if I have two parts in my network, which means two executors, e1 and e2. The whole training process can be described as:

```
e1.forward(is_train=True)
output1 = e1.outputs[0].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy()
...process output1 and get input2 for e2...
e2.arg_dict["data"][:] = input2
e2.forward(is_train=True)
output2 = e2.outputs[0].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy()
...calculate gradients for output2 say grad2...
e2.backward(mx.ndarray.array(grad2))
data_grad = e2.grad_dict["data"].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy() //get gradients for data
...process data_grad and get grad_output1 for e1...
e1.backward(mx.ndarray.array(grad_outpu1))
for arg in update_list:
    updater(...)
```

So is this the correct way of doing this? Since I used too many copyto(mx.cpu()) to force the sync, would this cause any slow-down? If this is non-optimal, what is the best way to implement this? Thank you very much.
Activation with python command also makes sense. But please use a separate on/off switch api instead of modifying existing interface.

If each line is 120*1000 then you have to set `data_shape=(1,120000)`. Also, if you have labels in the CSV you have to put the same shape. But the label tag is optional. Then the csv will read in every iternation a number of lines equals to `batch_size`.
For `ADD_LDFLAGS`, it should be `-L`

@javelinjs Yep, that's true. I have another issue on loading the model's `json` file. 

(Now MXNet compiled without cndnn) I trained a model using Python and try to use its params and json in Scala. But got this error: 

> Exception in thread "main" ml.dmlc.mxnet.MXNetError: Failed loading Op pooling0 of type Pooling: Cannot find argument 'global_pool', Possible Arguments:
> kernel : Shape(tuple), required
>     pooling kernel size: (y, x)
> pool_type : {'avg', 'max', 'sum'}, required
>     Pooling type to be applied.
> stride : Shape(tuple), optional, default=(1,1)
>     stride: for pooling (y, x)
> pad : Shape(tuple), optional, default=(0,0)
>     pad for pooling: (y, x)

Isn't the `json` and `params` file are language-agnostic which can be easily used somewhere else? Or have I miss something?

I guess it is the `global_pool` argument in Python's API cause this error, as we don't have this argument in Scala-pkg. 

``` json
    {
      "op": "Pooling", 
      "param": {
        "global_pool": "False", 
        "kernel": "(19,1)", 
        "pad": "(0,0)", 
        "pool_type": "max", 
        "stride": "(1,1)"
      }, 
      "name": "pooling0", 
      "inputs": [[4, 0]], 
      "backward_source_id": -1
    },
```

Since there is no dependency between the de-allocation and other allocations.
- Currently later issued operations are allowed to happen before previously issued operations, if there are no dependencies. 
- The order cannot be enforced because there is no dependencies between these, unless we change the programming model, which could restrict the ability to do out of order computation
What arch are you using? Is this due to the change of padding in pooling? @piiswrong @antinucleon
I think maybe is Downsample Factory.

Doc build on readthedocs has been broken for a while due to time out.
Let's move it to EC2...
We can actually have a variable for each device and make all alloc/dealloc write to that variable.
what @piiswrong suggested is correct, again that will serialize all the imperative operations, as opposed to execute them out of order
Not necessarily. For example we can have all alloc read from the common variable and dealloc write to it. Then as long as you are not deallocating nothing will be serialized
Another thing we can do is to sync engine whenever alloc fails. This will wait for all pending dealloc to finish before we are sure that we are really oom
You can generate it by `make doc`
For now the best fix is to call wait_to_read once in a while
This maybe caused by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2795, you should update cuda and cudnn to the latest version.

@sxjscience, I was considering your idea of basing my solution on MakeLoss and Relu, but, with the API as is, it's unfeasible to make a solution using just operators. The sign varies depending if it's a expected answer or not and since we don't have one_hot_encode implemented on C++, it is not possible to write it using just already implemented operators. I'll keep trying pure CUDA solutions

@tqchen I understand that it is still computationally correct to put alloc before dealloc. In fact we issue non-dependent operations out of order to achieve maximum parallelism. What I'm encountering here is a corner case where out of order execution might hurt usability. I think @piiswrong suggestion of calling sync when allocation fails is a good fix for now. It doesn't serialize most of the operations while still providing correct OOM behavior.
